body:
I can reproduce this on Linux, but not on macOS. The canonical repo name of a repo in runfiles changes between the two Bazel versions, which somehow causes staleness with respect to updating the runfiles tree.

@linzhp Could you check whether adding `--incompatible_use_plus_in_repo_names` with both Bazel versions fixes this for you?

CC @tjgq in case you have any idea where this runfiles tree staleness can come from. On Linux, I can no longer reproduce this with `--noexperimental_inprocess_symlink_creation`, so it looks like a bug in the update logic to me.

Edit: It's possible that only Bazel 7 is affected.

Edit 2: also happens with switched versions

Edit 3: I have a fix

issue.title: [8.4.0] Bazel 8.x may corrupt output base for Bazel 7.x

body: @iancha1992 We should treat this as a proper release blocker for 8.4.0 (incremental incorrectness), but I'm planning to submit a fix today.

issue.title: Fix runfiles directory staleness issues caused by symlinking the output manifest

labels.name: team-Configurability
labels.description: platforms, toolchains, cquery, select(), config transitions

repository.name: bazel
repository.description: a fast, scalable, multi-language and extensible build system

issue.body:
`SymlinkTreeAction` is only executed for its side effect of updating the runfiles tree, but its up-to-dateness is tracked solely by the digest of its output, the manifest under the runfiles directory. If this manifest is a symlink to the input manifest and a previous build modified the runfiles directory while not updating the action cache entry for `SymlinkTreeAction`, this would cause Bazel to consider the action up-to-date even though the runfiles directory is stale.

The fix consists of two parts:
* Always copy the manifest instead of symlinking it, matching the behavior of the former `--noexperimental_inprocess_symlink_creation` flag. This fixes staleness issues when only using versions of Bazel with this fix.
* Detect stale state left behind by older versions of Bazel by skipping action cache hits if the output manifest is a symlink. Since this situation is no longer created by fixed versions of Bazel, we could consider removing this logic in the future.

Fixes #26818
